Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Infrared (IR) Fluorescence Imager
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non Technical Abstract:
The LI-COR Odyssey Infrared Imaging System acquired through this award will enable highly quantitative investigations in diverse areas of research such as mitotic spindle function, muscle function, obesity, receptor function, and plant responses to heat stress. This instrument uses infrared (IR) technology for the highly sensitive and accurate measurement of biological molecules over several orders of magnitude, thus facilitating the detection of very low but biologically meaningful signals in a diverse group of applications, including protein and nucleic acid gels, protein arrays, In-Cell Westerns and tissue sections. Further, this instrumentation will be incorporated into undergraduate science education and research training programs in biology, biochemistry, neuroscience, and psychology.

Technical Abstract:
This highly sensitive imaging system will be used in a broad range of ongoing research projects, making previously qualitative assays quantitative. In particular, the Odyssey imaging system will be used to: a) examine the role of the protein myosin-10 in mitotic spindle function by facilitating dominant-negative analysis; b) investigate the involvement of high-fat-diet-induced changes in levels of the adipose hormone leptin in the hippocampus; c) analyze the contribution of the 3' untranslated region of the Rubisco activase gene to the stability of the Rubisco activase protein and thus to the heat stress response in plants; d) explore the role of perisynaptic glial cells at the neuromuscular junction by determining whether they express COX-2 in response to stimulation of their muscarinic acetylcholine receptors; and e) monitor the isolation and purification of neuronal nicotinic acetylcholine receptor subunits for use in studies to analyze drug-receptor interactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enabled Grinnell College to purchase an Odyssey CLx Infrared (IR) Imaging System. This system represents the leading edge in quantitative data acquisition for Western blotting and several other applications, including nucleic acid detection and imaging of tissue sections, and as such it has expanded the experimental options for quantitative data analyses in faculty and student research, as well as in classroom laboratory instruction. In addition to the instrument itself, the project financed purchase of startup materials and consumables essential for the use of the instrument, which were treated as shared resources for all users.

The instrument was purchased and installed in August 2014 and has been fully operational since, with no problems. The instrument has been used by members (students and faculty) of at least five different research labs in biology, biochemistry, chemistry, and psychology, as well as in the laboratory exercises of an Advanced Cell Biology course. The highest usage took place in the context of mentored undergraduate student research. Data generated has contributed to multiple undergraduate research presentations, several conference posters, and peer-reviewed articles (one published and one under review). This significant use of the instrument by undergraduate research students and faculty in the course of active investigations meets the stated goals of the proposed work.  

The instrumentation is low maintenance, both in terms of time and costs, and has been incorporated into the Biology department’s shared instrumentation suite. The Biology department is committed to the continued oversight of the instrument going forward. As Grinnell is a primarily undergraduate institution that embraces hands-on experiential learning as its primary mode of research training, it is expected that the Odyssey CLx IR Imaging System will continue to be used extensively in research and educational activities for years to come.
